Graphical abstract Esterification of formic acid with n-butanol was catalyzed by dodecatungstophosphoric acid, H3PW12O40 (DTP) impregnated on tonsil earth. A series of catalysts containing 10%, 20% and 30% of DTP on tonsil earth were synthesized. The samples were characterized by FT-IR, XRD, BET and TG. The 20% DTP loaded on tonsil showed the highest catalytic activity among the samples prepared in this study. Therefore the kinetics of esterification of formic acid with butanol has been studied in the presence of 20% DTP/T. The kinetic behavior of the reaction has been found to follow the Eley–Rideal model. Keywords 12-tungstophosphoric acid Tonsil earth Esterification Characterization Eley–Rideal model 1 Introduction Heteropoly acids (HPAs) have been widely used in numerous acid-catalyzed reactions due to their strong Bronsted acidity [1,2]. In homogeneous liquid-phase catalysis, the advantages of the HPAs are more distinctive due to their low volatility, low corrosiveness, high acidity, activity and ﬂexibility. The major disadvantages of HPAs, as catalyst lies in their low thermal stability, low surface area (1–10m2/g) and separation problem from reaction mixture [3]. HPAs on suitable supports are expected to overcome the above mentioned problems. A number of porous supports with high surface areas, such as silica [4,5] titania [5,6] alumina [5] active carbon [6,7], MCM-41 [8,9], acidic ion exchange resins [10], clay [11,12], have been used for supporting HPAs. Acid modiﬁed clay minerals can also be used as an efficient supports [13] because they exhibit higher surface area, pore volume, pore diameter and higher surface acidity [14] which results in its improved adsorption and catalytic properties. In particular, the acid treated clay catalysts have received considerable attention in different organic synthesis as a catalyst or as a support because of their environmental compatibility, low cost and operational simplicity. Using clay catalysts, one can conduct environmentally benign green chemistry both at industrial level and on laboratory scale. The acid strength of HPA supported on some of the materials mentioned above is lower than that of bulk HPA, due to the interaction of HPA with surface functional groups of supports. In cases of composite material, there is an inﬂuence of support on the acidity function of HPA and vice versa [15,16]. In the present work, synthesis of 12-tungstosilicicacid (DTS) and 12-tungstoposphoric acid supported with tonsil earth. A series of catalysts, which have high conversion, containing different percent heteropoly acid included were synthesized. The support and new amorphous catalysts have been characterized by FT-IR, XRD, particle size distribution and surface area measurement (BET method) and thermo gravimetric analyses (TGA). Their catalytic properties were evaluated for the esterification of formic acid with butanol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Tonsil earth was supplied from Ravin Company in Turkey. It is a fine, yellowish-grey powder and used for bleaching of vegetable and animal oil since it has a highly porous inner structure. Tonsil earth oxide composition is SiO2: 66.8%; Al2O3:14.2%; Fe2O3: 3.07%; MgO: 2.3%; CaO: 1.1%; Na2O:08%, K2O:2.2%. Other physical and chemical properties of tonsil earth are also given in Table 1 . The Merck quality of 12-tungstophosphoric acid (DTP) and 12-tungstosilicic acid (DTS) were used as the HPA. The other catalyst, Amberlyst-15, was purchased from Aldrich. Butyl alcohol (>99.5%) was obtained from Fluka. Formic acid (>99.5%) and dioxane, as the solvent, were supplied by Merck. 2.2 Catalyst preparation Loading of 20% DTP and DTS on tonsil earth was realized first. After finding that the catalyst containing DTP, between them, has higher activity the catalyst having 10%, 20% and 30% of DTP on tonsil earth were prepared by the incipient wetness impregnation method [17]. In this method, a known amount of tonsil earth was dried in an oven at 120°C for 1h. The measured heteropoly acid (HPA) was dissolved in methanol forming a homogeneous solution. The methanolic HPA solution was slowly added to the tonsil earth with constant stirring with the help of glass rod. Initially, supports were in powdered form; however, upon subsequent addition of methanolic HPA solution on them they form a paste or wet cake. Further kneading of the paste for 10min yielded a dry free flowing powder. The preformed catalyst was dried in an oven at 120°C for 1h and then calcined at 275°C for 3h. The prepared catalysts were kept in desiccators for experiments. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The crystallinity and the phase purity of synthesized samples were analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns by using X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Rind 2000, Japan), and Cu-Kα (1.54Å) radiation. XRD was performed within 2θ range of 10°–70°. The BET (Brunauer–Emmett–Taller) speciﬁc surface area was obtained from N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm measured at 77K in an automatic adsorption apparatus (ASAP2010; micrometritics). N2 vapor adsorption data was obtained at the vapor pressure range (P/P o ) of 0.03–0.3. The speciﬁc surface area was calculated by using multipoint BET method. The pore size distributions were also determined by the BJH (Barret–Joyner–Halenda) method using the N2 desorption isotherm. Prior to measurement, samples were degassed at 275°C for 2h. FTIR studies of the catalysts were conducted by using a Bruker IFS-66 single channel Fourier transform spectrophotometer. Thin wafers were prepared by mixing 0.004g of the catalysts with 0.196g of KBr. Thermal analysis was carried out using a NETZSCH STA 409 PC/PG thermal analyzer. The samples with mass of about 10mg were placed in alumina crucible .The measurements were performed in dynamic nitrogen atmosphere with the flow rate of 50mLmin−1, in the temperature range of 20–750°C with a heating rate of 10°Cmin−1. 2.4 Esterification reactions The catalytic experiments were carried out in a stirred batch reactor at reflux conditions. In a typical experiment, dioxane as the solvent and one of the reactant were placed in the reactor. A known amount of catalyst was added and the reactor contents were well mixed. After a steady value of desired temperature was attained, the second reactant was added and this was taken as zero time for the run. Two milliliters of liquid sample was withdrawn from the reactor at regular intervals for analysis and immediately transferred to a crucible in an ice bath in order to ensure that no further reaction took place. Formic acid, in the reaction mixture, was determined by titration with 0.1N standard sodium hydroxide solutions with phenolphthalein as an indicator. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalysts 3.1.1 FTIR The primary structures of supported HPAs (Proton form) were identified by comparing their FT-IR absorbance bands to those of bulk DTP, DTS and tonsil (Fig. 1 ). Bulk DTP in Fig. 1(d) shows the characteristic IR bands at ca. 1080cm−1 (P–O in central tetrahedral), 983cm−1 (terminal W =O), and 890 and 797cm−1 (W–O–W) associated with the asymmetric vibrations in the Keggin polyanion (Fig. 1(d and e)) which matches very well with that of the finding of Kozhevnikov et al. [8–17] and also bulk DTS gives similar vibrations in Fig. 1(e). The scan of DTP/K-10 and DSP/K-10, (Fig. 1 (b and c)) are similar to that of tonsil except that they have a prominent peak at 891cm−1 which indicated W-O-W vibrations. The shift observed for this peak when compared to pure DTP could be attributed to the interaction between DTP and tonsil the same interaction was also observed between DTS and tonsil. 3.1.2 XRD The primary structures of supported HPAs (Proton form) were identified by comparing their XRD patterns to those of bulk DTP, DTS and tonsil (Fig. 2 ). Bulk DTP and DTS in Fig. 2 shows the similar characteristic patterns in the Keggin polyanion (Fig. 2 (e and f)) which matches very well with literature [18]. On the other hand Fig. 2 (a) shows that tonsil earth is in an amorphous state rather than in a crystal state. By comparing the XRD patterns of DTP and DTS, it can be noted that neither of the catalysts showed peaks that can be assigned to this active phase, which indicates that the supported WP is well dispersed on the-surface of the supports. This good dispersion can be related to the mean pore diameter of the supports (tonsil), which is about 38Å (see Table 2 ) while the diameter of the HPA is about 12Å [20]. This difference in the pore diameter allows a more uniform distribution of HPA on the support's surface, minimizing the possibility of agglomerations of HPA which could induce crystallization and pore plug [19]. 3.1.3 Nitrogen adsorption The textural properties of the different prepared catalysts were studied by N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms method. The related textural data of the catalysts are reported in Table 2 and the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms are shown in Fig. 3 . The supporter tonsil earth, showed an initial surface area of 179m2/g and pore volume of 0.67cm3/g. The surface area and total pore volume decreases as the amount of DTP loading increases, for instance, 30% DTP loading the surface area and the total pore volume becomes 109m2/g and 0.37cm3/g respectively. The reduction in surface area and pore volume upon DTP loading may be due to the blockage of pores by DTP molecules, because of the diameter of the WP molecule (approx. 12Å) [20] is smaller than that of the average mesopore size (∼38Å) of the supporter, which usually leads to a decrease in pore diameter. The typical isotherms of N2 adsorption–desorption given in Fig. 3a, b and c show that they have the type IV isotherms with the hysteresis loop of the type H3, which is a characteristic of a mesoporous solids [20]. 3.1.4 Thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) The thermal analyses have been carried out on bulk DTP, DTS, tonsil earth, 20% DTP/T, and 20% DTS/T samples. The results of these analyses are reported in Fig. 4 . The TGA of 12-tungstophosphoric acid shows a weight loss of about 4% up to a temperature of 300°C, indicating loss of free and adsorbed water. The gradual weight loss of about 1% up to 700°C corresponds to the mass loss due to the reaction between acidic protons and structural oxygen from phosphotungstic acid, releasing water, followed by decomposition to WO3 and POx species. [16] The thermal data of tonsil shows a steady loss of weight of about 12% up to 700°C; such a loss is attributed to the loss of physisorbed and interlayer water and also due to dehydroxylation caused by the breaking of structural OH-groups of the support. The TGA of supported DTP and DTS onto tonsil shows about 8% weight loss over 300°C due to a loss of adsorbed water molecule. A gradual weight loss of about 3% up to 700°C was also observed, such a result indicates an increase in the thermal stability of DTP on tonsil. This may be due to the formation of intermolecular bonding between the support and heteropoly acid and indicates the presence of chemical interaction between the support and heteropoly acid. 3.1.5 Stability of DTP on tonsil earth The stability of DTP on tonsil earth was evaluated by the characteristic heteropoly blue color test recommended by Yadav [17,21].The results of the test shows that the leaching of DTP on tonsil earth was not occurred in the test solution. Additionally, XRD patterns of the catalyst were obtained before and after reaction. The results are shown in Fig. 2. As seen in Fig. 2, DTP on tonsil earth is not dissolved in the reaction mixture since XRD patterns of the catalyst are almost the same before and after the reaction. 3.2 Effect of parameters on the reaction rate The effects of parameters; such as catalyst type and loading, agitation speed, temperature and reactant mole ratio on the reaction rate for the esterification of formic acid with butanol were studied. 3.2.1 Catalytic activity Different types of catalysts prepared in this study were tested as the heterogeneous catalysts for the esterification reaction between formic acid and butanol. Experiments were carried out at 343K and M =1 with C A0 =2mol/L for 3h, in the presence of 5% (w/w) catalyst in the reaction mixture for each types. Results are given in Table 3 . Product selectivity depending on the catalysts type is not considered in this study since byproducts formation was not detected. As seen from Table 3 that the conversion of acid in 3h is 10.8% for uncatalyzed reaction. Then, the catalytic activities of all types of catalysts were compared with this value. Tonsil earth containing no HPA has the lowest activity among the all catalyst. It was also shown that the catalyst loaded by DTP is more active than the one loaded by DTS. This results is attributed to the acidic strength of DTP which is higher than that of DTS [4,22,23]. Therefore, the study of the esterification reaction was conducted in the presence of DTP/T catalyst. It was observed that the catalytic activity of 20% DTP/T is the highest compared to the 10% and 30% DTP/T since the surface area in 30% DTP/T is lower than that of the 20% DTP/T because the excess amount of DTP can block the pore of the tonsil earth. It is also interesting to note that the activity of free DTP is signiﬁcantly lower than that of loaded on tonsil earth. The enhanced activity may be attributed to a high dispersion of DTP on tonsil, providing more surface area and active sites than that of the pure DTP. Table 3 also revealed that 20% DTP/T catalyst has higher activity than that of the commercial catalyst Amberlyst-15. 3.2.2 Effect of catalyst loading Experiments were carried out in reaction mixture containing 41, 82 and 125g/L of 20% of DTP/T under the constant conditions of 343K temperature and M =1 with C A0 =2mol/L. The reaction rate, up to about 10% conversion, can be considered to be a linear function of time. Therefore the initial reaction rate can be safely calculated by Eq. (1). (1) − r A,O = C A,O X A t Applying the Eq. (1) to the experimental data obtained at the conversion not higher than 10%, the initial reaction rate was calculated. A plot of the initial reaction rate vs. catalyst loading is given in Fig. 5 . As seen in Fig. 5, the reaction rate, as expected, is increasing linearly with catalyst loading since the active surface area is proportional to the amount of catalyst. The point determined by the intersection of the line with ordinate is in good agreement with the uncatalyst reaction rate obtained experimentally at given parameters. The mathematical expression relating the initial reaction rate to the catalyst loading can be derived from Fig. 5 as follows; (2) − r A,O ( molL − 1 min − 1 ) = 0.0005 + 0.0004 C cat ( molL − 1 ) It should also be kept in mind that Eq. (2) is valid only at the given parameters of 343K and M =1 with C A0 =1.94mol/L at which the experiments were performed. However, it does not alter the conclusion that the general reaction rate increases linearly with the catalyst loading. 3.2.3 Effect of speed of agitation To investigate the external mass transfer resistance the experiment were carried out at 200, 400 and 700rpm under the same reaction conditions of 343K, M =1 with C A0 =2mol/L, and catalyst loading of 40g/L in reaction mixture. Results are given in Fig. 6 . As seen in Fig. 6, the reaction rate is almost independent of the stirring speed. Therefore, the experiments were realized at constant stirring speed of 300rpm. From this analysis, it was concluded that the reaction is not external diffusion controlled. That is; the reaction is not internal diffusion control. Therefore all experiments to analyze the kinetics of reaction were performed at catalyst loading of 40g/L in reaction mixture. 3.2.4 Effect of temperature Esterification reaction was realized at different temperatures of 328, 343 and 358K under the constant reaction conditions of M =1 with C A0 =2mol/L, and the catalyst concentration of 40g/L in reaction mixture. Results are given in Fig. 7 . As seen in Fig. 7, the reaction rate strongly depends on temperature. This is another verification of the fact that the reaction is not controlled by internal and external diffusion steps but chemical reaction step since chemical change is always more temperature sensitive than physical steps. 3.2.5 Effect of initial reactants mole ratio Initial reaction rate was determined by altering the concentration of the component under investigation while keeping that of the others constant at temperature of 343K and the catalyst concentration of 40g/L in reaction mixture. The reaction rate, up to about 10% conversion, can be considered to be a linear function of time. Therefore, the initial reaction rate can be safely calculated by Eq. (1). Applying the Eq. (1) to the experimental data obtained at the conversion not higher than 10%, the initial reaction rate was calculated. A plot of the initial reaction rate vs. concentration is given in Figs. 8–10 . As seen in Fig. 8, butyl alcohol is not adsorbed on the catalyst since the initial reaction rate is increasing linearly, rather than producing a figure of plateau, with increasing its concentrations. On the other hand Figs. 9 and 10 indicate that formic acid and water are adsorbed on the catalyst since the initial reaction rate is becoming nearly independent of the concentrations as their corresponding values increases [24]. 3.3 Kinetic modeling 3.3.1 Determination of the equilibrium constant The apparent equilibrium constant of the reaction can be found from the equilibrium conversions, determined experimentally, as follows; (3) K e = X A,e 2 ( 1 − X A,e ) ( M − X A,e ) In Eq. (3) the equilibrium constant is stated in terms of concentration instead of activities since activity can be defined as a i = γ i c i and the coefficient γ i can readily be combined with constant. Furthermore, the usage of concentrations is more practical than that of activities. The reaction was carried out up to the equilibrium conversion at different temperatures of 328, 343 and 358K. Temperature dependency of the equilibrium constant was also determined by applying van’t Hoff equation. The result is shown in Fig. 6. From Fig. 11 , the equilibrium constant, depending on temperature, was found to be (4) K e = exp 6.539 − 1982 T where T is absolute temperature in Kelvin. The heat of reaction, assuming independent of temperature ranging from 328 to 358K, calculated to be, ΔH r =1.982×8.314=16.47kJ/mol. 3.3.2 Reaction rate without catalyst (5) HCOOH ( A ) + C 4 H 9 OH ( B ) ⇔ k 2 k 1 C 4 H 9 COOH ( E ) + H 2 O ( W ) (6) − r A = k 1 C A C B − C E C W K Eq. (5) can be rearranged in terms of conversion, assuming that there is no product initially, as (7) − r A = C A,O d X A d t = k 1 C C A,O 2 ( 1 − X A ) ( M − X A ) − X A 2 K The uncatalyzed reaction was carried out at different temperatures of 328, 343 and 358K without catalyst The forward reaction rate constant, k 1, in Eq. (7) was determined by applying nonlinear regression analysis in MATLAB 7.0 program to the experimental data for each temperature. Results together with its confidence limits are given in Table 4 . Applying the Arrhenius equation to the values in Table 4, the temperature dependency of the rate constant, as well as its corresponding activation energy were found to be; k 1 ( L / mol min ) = exp 11.758 − 6871 T E = 57.125 KJ / mol where T is absolute temperature in K. 3.3.3 Reaction rate with catalyst Fig. 8 indicates that the initial reaction rate increases linearly with alcohol concentration. As seen in Fig. 9, the initial reaction rate, measured at different acid concentrations, increases linearly within the region of low acid concentrations, but it is nearly independent of acid concentrations at high levels. On the other hand, Fig. 10 shows that the initial forward reaction rate decreases with water concentration. From this analysis, it was concluded that while the acid and water are adsorbed on the catalyst surface the other species are not. These results indicate that Eley–Rideal model is applicable for the reaction mechanism, that is, the reaction takes place between adsorbed molecules of acid and water molecules and that of alcohol and ester in the bulk solution. The adsorption of solvent (dioxane) and ester were reported to be negligible [4–6]. Therefore, the general reaction mechanism and corresponding rate expression can be given by: A + S ⇔ k − 1 k 1 A × S A × S + B ⇔ k − 2 k 2 E + W × S W × S ⇔ k − 3 k 3 W + S (8) − r A = k 2 K A w C A C B − C E C W K 1 + K A C A + K W C W where K A = k 1 k − 1 , K W = k 3 / k − 3 The forward reaction rate constant, alcohol and water adsorption equilibrium constant, k 2, K A and K W in Eq. (8) was determined by applying nonlinear regression analysis in MATLAB 7.0 program to the experimental data for each temperature. In this fitting the mean square differences between calculated and experimental values of rate was minimized as shown in Eq. (9). (9) min ϕ = ∑ allsamples r cal − r exp 2 The constants with their standard deviation at 95% confidence interval are given in Table 5 . Experimental results were then compared with those of the model prediction through the values of the mean relative deviation (MRD) between experimental and calculated conversions. (10) MRD = 1 n ∑ allsamples X A,cal − X A,exp X A,exp × 100 The MRDs calculated by Eq. (10) are also given in Table 5. The temperature dependency of the constants in Table 5 as well as their corresponding activation energies and adsorption heat were found to be; k 2 ( L/gcat mol min ) = exp 1.39 − 3200 T E = 26.61 kJ / mol K A ( L/mol ) = exp 1675 T − 1.86 Δ H = − 13.93 kJ / mol K W ( L/mol ) = exp 5062 T − 10.79 Δ H = − 42.09 kJ / mol where T is absolute temperature in K. 3.3.4 Comparison of model and experimental data Using the numerical values of the reaction rate constants given in Tables 4 and 5 and the Eqs. (7) and (8) was solved simultaneously by applying Runge-Kutta method for the chosen temperature. Thus, conversion-time curves based on the models were obtained under given uncatalyzed and catalyzed reaction conditions. These curves, together with the experimental data, are shown in Figs. 12 and 13 . As seen in Figs. 12 and 13, there is a reasonably good agreement between calculated curves and experimental points. 4 Conclusions In the present work, synthesis of 12-tungstosilicicacid (DTS) and 12-tungstoposphoric acid supported with tonsil were realized. The catalysts having 20% of DTP and DTS were synthesized first. Then, they have been characterized by FT-IR, XRD, TGA and surface area measurement (BET method). FTIR spectra and XRD patterns showed the interaction between HPA and tonsil. The results of BET analysis indicated that the surface area and total pore volume of tonsil decreases as the amount of DTP loading increases. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms also show that it is a characteristic of a mesoporous solid. On the other hand, TGA analysis of tonsil supporting DTP and DTS has higher stability than that of its bulk form. 20% DTP/T catalyst is the most active catalyst among the others since it gives the highest conversion (41.9%) under the same reaction conditions for esterification of the formic acid and butanol in 3h. Therefore, the kinetics of esterification of formic acid with butanol has been studied batchwise in the presence of 20% DTP/T as heterogeneous catalyst. The kinetic behavior of the reaction has been found to follow the Eley–Rideal model. References [1] M.R. Altıokka A. Çıtak Appl. Catal. A: Gen. 239 2003 141 148 [2] R. Chitnis M.M. Sharma React. coredata.dc:description: Esterification of formic acid with n-butanol was catalyzed by dodecatungstophosphoric acid, H3PW12O40 (DTP) impregnated on tonsil earth. A series of catalysts containing 10%, 20% and 30% of DTP on tonsil earth were synthesized. The samples were characterized by FT-IR, XRD, BET and TG. The 20% DTP loaded on tonsil showed the highest catalytic activity among the samples prepared in this study. Therefore the kinetics of esterification of formic acid with butanol has been studied in the presence of 20% DTP/T. The kinetic behavior of the reaction has been found to follow the Eley–Rideal model.
coredata.dc:title: Impregnation of 12-tungstophosphoric acid on tonsil: An effective catalyst for esterification of formic acid with n-butyl alcohol and kinetic modeling
